identificationModule.briefTitle: Prediction of Fluid Responsiveness by NICOM (Non-invasive Cardiac Output Monitoring) in Children With Congenital Heart Disease After Cardiac Surgery

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the ability of fluid responsiveness by stroke volume variation value of NICOM(Noninvasive cardiac output monitor)system during congenital cardiac surgery.

interventions.name: volume expansion
interventions.description: fluid loading of 10 ml/kg colloid or blood product

primaryOutcomes.description: Volume loading was performed for 20 minutes. Stroke volume measured before and after volume expansion using transesophageal echocardiography. And, stroke volume variation of NICOM monitor was recorded before fluid loading.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: before and after volume loading (20 min)

secondaryOutcomes.description: Cardiac index measured by transesophageal echocardiography and NICOM monitor were compared before and after fluid loading for 20 min.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: before and after fluid loading (20 min)

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* congenital cardiac surgery
* \< 6 years old
* who were required the evaluation by transesophageal echocardiography

Exclusion Criteria:

* right heart failure
* supported by more than 2 inotropic agents
* reduced kidney function
* any valvar stenosis
* moderate or severe tricuspid regurgitation
* single ventricle

references.citation: Lee JH, No HJ, Song IK, Kim HS, Kim CS, Kim JT. Prediction of fluid responsiveness using a non-invasive cardiac output monitor in children undergoing cardiac surgery. Br J Anaesth. 2015 Jul;115(1):38-44. doi: 10.1093/bja/aev109. Epub 2015 Apr 29.
